node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text: For most of 2020 the theory that covid-19 leaked from a Chinese lab was dismissed as unlikely. In the past few months it has gained currency. Our experts explain why. Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: Did covid-19 leak from a Chinese lab?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in London, United Kingdom. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'Britain Boris Johnson will break a promise and raise taxes to "fix" social care er CIAL CARE'.

node.text:
Boris Johnson vowed to fix the social-care crisis and to not raise taxes. Yet there is a problem with making contradictory promises: you can only keep one.⁠
⁠
Britain’s prime minister argued the covid-19 pandemic had unexpectedly increased costs for social care, which is true. Handily, the money can also be used to fund the prime minister’s social-care “fix”.⁠
⁠
The tax rise is popular, according to a recent poll. A plurality say it was acceptable to break the manifesto in order to fund social care. ⁠
⁠
But that may not tell the full story. Tap the link in our bio to find out why.⁠
⁠
Credit: Paul Edwards / WPA Pool / Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Yemen. May be an image of 1 person, standing and sky.

node.text:
Both Barack Obama and Donald Trump tried and failed to turn their backs on the Middle East. Joe Biden is unlikely to do so either. However, America’s place in the region—measured in troop levels, diplomatic engagement or influence—is not what it was.⁠
⁠
The Arab world is too big and diverse to be dominated by one ideology. It needs greater unity, but of the boring, technocratic sort.⁠
⁠
Young populations need jobs, the energy transition may gut the budgets of oil-producing states and climate change could make parts of the region unfit to live in. ⁠
⁠
If the Arab world’s leaders cannot stop fighting over old ideologies, they may find there is nothing left to fight for. Read the full Special report on the Arab world by tapping the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Mohammed Hamoud/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 07, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'Asia Yale-NUS the first liberal-arts college in Singapore, closes its doors YALF YALF-NUS COLLEG COLLEGE AVENUE'.

node.text:
When the current crop of first-years graduate, Yale-NUS, Singapore’s first liberal-arts college, will cease to exist.⁠
⁠
The university's launch was billed as a grand experiment testing whether an American-style liberal-arts education could sink roots in Asia.⁠
⁠
But at a meeting on August 27th administrators announced that the college’s programmes will be combined with another at NUS to form a new institution by 2022.⁠
⁠
The news came as a shock to students, teachers and the college president, Tan Tai Yong, who were not consulted.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to find out if the decision could have been more to do with politics, rather than education.⁠
⁠
Credit: Roslan Rahman/AFP via Getty Images

node.text:
What can America’s “gilded age” reveal about China’s future? On our “Money Talks” podcast we look back at a period in American history marked by tremendous growth married with inequality and corruption, and ask whether this might help us understand China’s near future.⁠
⁠
Also on the podcast, how the Delta variant is changing the direction of the world economy, and why video-gaming is China’s latest target in its crackdown on big technology.⁠
⁠
To hear more about markets, the economy and business, click the link in our bio to listen to “Money Talks”

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 07, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'Science & technology How to improve the intelligence of self-driving cars'.

node.text:
By the age of seven months, most children have learned that objects still exist even when they are out of sight. ⁠
⁠
This understanding of “object permanence” is a basic tenet of reality. It is also something that autonomous vehicles do not have. And that is a problem.⁠
⁠
For a self-driving car, a bicycle that is momentarily hidden by a passing van is a bicycle that has ceased to exist.⁠
⁠
Current AI works by building up complex statistical models of the world, but it lacks a deeper understanding of reality. How to give AI at least some semblance of that understanding is now a matter of active research.⁠
⁠
Mehul Bhatt of Orebro University, in Sweden, and his colleagues took some existing AI programs which are used by self-driving cars and bolted onto them a piece of software called a symbolic-reasoning engine.⁠
⁠
To read how it performed, tap the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @cristina.spano

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 07, 2021. May be an image of map and text that says 'Poorly evised regulation lets firms pollute with abandon US, difference inair air pollution between monitored and unmonitored days, by county, 2001-13 Pollut higher on Monitored days 个 ↓ Unmonitored days Source: "Unwatched pollution: the effect of intermittent monitoring on air quality", by Eric Yongchen Zou, 2021 The Economist'.

node.text:
Athletes don’t get advance warning of drug tests. Police don’t share details of planned raids. Yet America’s Environmental Protection Agency does not seem convinced of the value of surprise when it comes to pollution.⁠
⁠
Every year it publishes a list of dates, spaced at six-day intervals, on which it will require state and local agencies to provide data on concentrations of harmful fine particulate matter, such as soot or cement dust.⁠
⁠
A new paper by Eric Zou of the University of Oregon has made use of satellite images to spy on polluters at times when they think no one is watching. It showed their air was consistently cleaner on monitoring days than it was the rest of the time.⁠
⁠
But click the link in our bio to read how fines and sanctions can actually make a difference.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Lebanon. May be an image of text that says 'NEVER ORDER TABBOULEH OUTSIDE LEBANON'.

node.text:
“Each mouthful takes us back to our earliest memories of family and community.”⁠
⁠
Tabbouleh, a Lebanese salad with tangy flavours, doesn’t have many ingredients, but its assembly is extraordinarily labour-intensive.⁠
⁠
To understand the dish, it's best to forget your previous experiences. ⁠
⁠
People in crisis-stricken Lebanon find solace in a dish that smells of mint, mountains and happy memories. But as @1843mag explains, foreign chefs cannot seem to get it right.⁠
⁠
To find out why it tastes so bad elsewhere, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @mggillustration

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in San Francisco, California. May be an image of 1 person, standing, suit and text that says 'Business What Intel's el'sturnaround could mean for the future of chipmaking'.

node.text:
Intel has long guarded its core chipmaking business as jealously as Microsoft did its operating system. ⁠
⁠
Product delays and misplaced bets have dogged the American semiconductor giant. But Pat Gelsinger (pictured), its third CEO in as many years, intends to leave those behind.⁠
⁠
If successful, his strategy could reshape a $600bn industry at the heart of the fast-digitising global economy for the better. ⁠
⁠
Failure could compound chip shortages and could lead to further concentration of the already cosy chipmaking market. And it may cement Asia’s dominance of the industry, creating all kinds of geopolitical complications.⁠
⁠
The stakes are high—and not just for Intel. To read why, click on the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Eric Millette/The Forbes Collection/Contour RA by Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The future of American power Polarisation and schisms within the United States could in time lead to a serious breakdown of public order Arundhati Roy'.

node.text:
"The real tragedy for the United States is not the debacle in Afghanistan, but that it was played out on live television," argues Arundhati Roy in a piece for The Economist.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"The resurgent Taliban humiliated the United States," writes the novelist and essayist. But back home, America now faces bigger worries, from social polarisation to environmental collapse, she says.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"The polarisation and schisms within the United States could in time lead to a serious breakdown of public order. We've already seen the early signs," she warns.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Furthermore, "American geography is on notice," she writes. "Its natural bounty can no longer sustain the 'American way of life'—or war".⁠⁠
⁠⁠
To read what Arundhati Roy believes America's fiery, brutal impotence means for the country's future, click on the link in our bio.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Illustration: @dan.will

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The future of American power Polarisation and schisms within the United States could in time lead to a serious breakdown of public order Arundhati Roy'.
Photo by The Economist on September 07, 2021. May be a drawing of 1 person.
Photo by The Economist in London, United Kingdom.

node.text:
The end of the summer feels too early to be thinking about Christmas, but retailers in Britain have little choice. ⁠
⁠
The typical household spends around a third more than usual in December, and stocking up for the most important trading weeks of the year usually begins around now. ⁠
⁠
This year, however, rather than preparing for the coming rush, retailers are struggling to keep shelves full.⁠
⁠
So what is causing shortages in Britain? Tap the link in our bio to read about the bottlenecks, and how covid-19 and Brexit have reshaped the economy.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @lo_cole

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Malang. May be an image of one or more people and text.

node.text:
Sunti Ani has been arrested more times than she can count. Her crime is being a sex worker in Indonesia.⁠
⁠
She lives in Malang, in the province of East Java, where her trade was criminalised in 2014 on the basis that prostitution is “prohibited by all religions”.⁠
⁠
The ban has meant that sex workers’ earnings fell and some compensated by offering clients unprotected sex, for which they can charge more.⁠
⁠
Public-health measures have suffered as well. Many prostitutes in Malang lost access to cheap condoms and checks for sexually transmitted infections.⁠
⁠
But two brothels in a nearby district remained open. Click the link in our bio to read how this in turn created a natural experiment about infection rates in those premises.⁠
⁠
Image credit: Ulet Ifansasti/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 06, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'International From Congo to the Capitol, conspiracy theories are surging ? HOAX! 3m 42.5m views $'.

node.text:
The pandemic has produced a tsunami of misinformation—and the internet makes it easier than ever to spread it.⁠
⁠
In France a documentary alleging that covid-19 was invented by political elites as part of a conspiracy to bring about a “new world order” was watched 2.5m times in three days.⁠
⁠
And in America the notion that covid is a hoax has spread alongside a collection of feverish theories known as “QAnon”, which hold that the government is run by a secret cabal of paedophiles and that Donald Trump is a saviour destined to defeat them. There are 45 believers in QAnon running for Congress in 2022.⁠
⁠
This is, in short, a golden age of conspiracy theories. They are at least as common in poor countries as in rich ones.⁠
⁠
Bonkers beliefs have existed throughout history. But to get a sense of how they infect politics today, a good place to start is the Democratic Republic of Congo. To read why, and to learn how they can be discouraged, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @wylesol_
